dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BRILLIANT NIGHT SKY. Cloudless and pure with a dazzling array of stars. BURNING EMBERS drift upwards followed by tongues of FIRE reaching into the blackness. Then the SOUND of FEROCIOUS COMBAT rises. Swords clashing pistols roaring along with the cries of the dying. The stars and embers are suddenly replaced by THE FACE OF FIERCE WARRIOR. He screams a ferocious challenge. There’s murder in his eyes as... ...he raises a vicious scimitar, it catches the light of the fires nearby and he... HAS A HOLE BLOWN THROUGH HIS HEAD. As the victim collapses out of frame we see the killer still holding his two smoking MATCHLOCK PISTOLS - this is SOLOMON KANE, swordsman, Naval Captain, mercenary, buccaneer and servant of the Queen of England. He turns t the MEN following him.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: No mercy to heathens! Advance! ! He smoothly holsters his pistols and unsheathes his two signature swords - a CUTLASS and a RAPIER. He deflects a flurry of attacks from his enemies and cuts them down without a thought. It is obvious he is a martia expert with these weapons as he drives forward. SOLOMON KANE is in his early thirties but it’s hard tell through the history of violence and adventure which has weathered his face. He’s masculine but wolf slim with lon dark hair tied back, intense, predatory eyes and pale ski now spattered in the blood of his victims. He’s dressed i ornate, expensive clothes where, somewhere beneath all th finery is the uniform of a Captain in the Queens Navy. Wi the trims and excess of his own choosing he looks unique and exotic - a murderous dandy. Kane hacks at another of the city’s defenders. Sidesteps yet another sweeping scimitar and delivers death with eve thrust of his rapier. He is unstoppable.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 2 At his back Kane’s own PLATOON OF MARINES follow. Equally relentless and bloodthirsty as their commander are a wedg of PIKEMEN, ARCHERS and SWORDSMEN driving further and further into the city’s defences. Further behind still, is the SEA PORT where they entered this glittering, exotic and magical city where an ENGLISH NAVAL TALL SHIP is moored. The HARBOUR and MUCH OF THE CI BY THE SHORE IS BURNING FIERCELY. The path of destruction and fire is like a wake left behind by Kane’s advance. The whole city seems to be in a panic. WOMAN and CHILDREN screaming in fear, MEN rushing to defend their homes, NATIVE WARRIORS launching attacks on Kane’s soldiers but nothing seems to be able to stop them. One of KANE’S OWN MEN rushes past him, fleeing from a MOB of the city’s defenders. Kane pulls a pistol, takes aim.. He SHOOTS HIS OWN MAN IN THE BACK. The man crashes to the ground, screaming as a dozen scimitar blades hack him to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Faithless coward. Kane, sweating and blood-spattered, dashes forward, eyes gleaming.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: On-me men! See; there’s our goal! Perched on the cliff overlooking the city is a CASTLE OF BLACK OBSIDIAN. Almost organic in its lines and architecture it sits impassive; a careless guardian of th burning city beneath. A handful of his men make it to his side. Fighting all th way. One, LIEUTENANT MALTHUS, at Kane’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MALTHUS
dialogues.text: Captain, what about the prisoners we’re supposed to rescue?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Malthus; you take care of that.

dialogues.speaker: MALTHUS
dialogues.text: What are you going to do Captain? Kane grins like a wolf.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I have a different prize in mind. Cooper! COOPER, a great brute of a man fights his way towards Kan  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 3

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Send half the men with Malthus.

dialogues.speaker: COOPER
dialogues.text: And the rest?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: See that black tower ahead?

dialogues.speaker: COOPER
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: It’s the one the slave girl told us about.

dialogues.speaker: COOPER
dialogues.text: You don’t believe her Solomon? She would have said anything to save herself. There’s no fortune to be had.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Perhaps but I’1l be long dead before I pass up a chance like this.

dialogues.speaker: MALTHUS
dialogues.text: Is that the real reason we came to this barbarian place Captain; just to line your pockets further? Kane laughs even as they both stop to fight off a FRESH WAVE OF ATTACKERS.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: You have no ambition Malthus; that’s your principal failing.

dialogues.speaker: MALTHUS
dialogues.text: At least I know the difference between good and evil.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Which is why you will never have the riches or power that I have. Now follow your orders!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOZENS OF DEFENDING CASTLE GUARDS are slamming the heavy main doors and barricading them. Holding the wooden bar i place as...  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 4 More and more SOLDIERS push in to defend. All marshalled the inner doors of the obsidian castle, they are heavily armed, disciplined and eager for a fight But SUDDENLY those doors SMASH INWARDS with a HUGE EXPLOSION of fire and gunpowder that TEARS THE HEAVY DOOR OFF THEIR HINGES. The SOLDIERS ARE BLOWN APART. The lucky ones are flung aside by the blast as a VORTEX OF FLAME howls down the hallway - tapestries, artwork and people all engulfed in the inferno. The GUARDS lie dead or dying. A wall of flame burns in th doorway. A FIGURE walks through the flames, leading a DOZEN MEN. He moves like a wolf, focussed and deadly. Long hair flying, black cloak whipped by the hot air and intense da eyes scanning the dead. This is SOLOMON KANE. Kane stops before one of the cowering GUARDS and levels h pistol at the man.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Where is the throne room? He repeats the line in the native language, aggressive, commanding. The man shields his face and points, indicating the direction and spitting out instructions. KANE takes in the information and then SHOOTS THE MAN, POINT BLANK.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: (to his men) This way! As KANE leads HIS DOZEN MEN further into the castle, he shoots and stabs every last one of the defenders. KANE SLAUGHTERS EVERY SURVIVOR. No one is spared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KANE and his MEN pass through inner doors and advance cautiously into the heart of the castle. There’s no further resistance now but no one is lowering their guard They enter a huge room filled with columns between which hang VAST BLACK MIRRORS. There are strange symbols etched into the surface - magical and ornate, rich in meaning.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 5

dialogues.speaker: COOPER
dialogues.text: What is this place?

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: We shouldn’t be here. Can’t you feel it? One of the soldier’s turns sharply.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: There’s something in here with us.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: (hissing to his men) Quiet! Keep moving. The other soldiers look around nervously but there’s nowhere for anything to hide. Kane studies his own reflection as he passes a mirror. In the surface he sees SOMETHING BEHIND HIM. He whirls round to confront his enemy but THERE IS NOTHING THERE apart fr an infinity of his own image caught between mirrors on th opposite wall. A little unnerved he advances. His men follow. As the last few men begin to move on again DARK FIGURES

dialogues.speaker: SUDDENLY REACH OUT FROM WITHIN THE MIRRORS. BLACK SKELETA
dialogues.text: ARMS EMBRACE KANE’S MEN. With muffled screams HALF OF THE SOLDIERS vanish, dragged back through the now liquid glass by the demons within. The doors of the corridor SLAM SHUT BEHIND THE OTHERS. Th remaining men start to panic. Swords and pistols at the ready but no enemy in sight. One sees his companion falli backwards into the darkness of the mirror...

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Captain...!

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Hold steady.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: There is devilry, I know it. Kane grabs the man, snarling.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I am the only devil here. Now move! Now the DOORS AHEAD OF THEM SWING OPEN.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 6 An invitation to advance into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KANE strides eagerly across the threshold into the THRONE ROOM. A cavernous, ornate space filled with grotesque statues of twisted figures caught in helpless agony.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: This is it lads. We’ve found it. He turns to his men - just as the throne room doors SLAM SHUT BEHIND HIM, cutting him off from his companions. He tries to tear the heavy doors open but they will not move There are no handles, no way to escape. He can hear SCREAMS from beyond the doors. A few brief moments of terror, one or two GUNSHOTS and cries of pain and then nothing but SILENCE. He turns back to the throne room and looks about him. Little light filters through the stained glass windows bu just enough to illuminate... ...the TREASURE piled around a vast, high-backed, black THRONE on a raised dais ahead. VAST WEALTH laid casually about in glittering mounds. Unafraid Kane steps further into the throne room. It seem deserted but he is ready with his weapons.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Show yourself! Or shall I take your treasure unopposed? Still nothing. Kane moves slowly forwards. He reaches dow to pick up some of the treasures then notices THE CORPSE THE KING lying beside his throne. Kane is suddenly unsure He whirls around to confront a sound but there is no one there.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Show yourself!! You should... He stops in mid sentence, unnerved, as THE SHADOWS AROUND THE ROOM SEEM TO MOVE AND TWIST before him. The air in the room freezes, his breath billows around hi clouds now. A CRACKING, BREAKING SOUND echoes around the room as ICE TENDRILS BEGIN TO SNAKE ACROSS the floor, towards the THRONE.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 7 FINGERS OF SMOKE AND SHADOW twist a whirl on the throne a little by little a SHAPE APPEARS. A FIGURE seemingly CLOTHED in BLACK SHADOWS that shift an change around him. It must be a man but it is so hard to see beyond the darkness that envelopes him. For fleeting, heart-stopping moments, the darkness takes form - somethi awful and corrupt - before becoming hazy and indistinct once again. Then the figure speaks. The voice seems to be coming from the very air itself. Powerful, resonant, insidious and beguiling. This is the Devil’s Reaper.

dialogues.speaker: REAPER
dialogues.text: Solomon Kane. Soldier, pirate thief, warrior... murderer. Kane holds his ground but knows he’s in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: You think I have not met sorcerers in my travels? I have no fear of you. A subsonic rumble fills the room. Kane says he has no fea but he’s growing nervous now.

dialogues.speaker: REAPER
dialogues.text: I am no mere sorcerer Kane. You know me. You know my master. He is your master too.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I have no master save the Queen. I ama...

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: It is a shattering sound. The power drives Kane to his knees. A darkness swallows the room for a moment and when it passes, there are low MOANS OF PAIN coming from all aroun the throne room. Kane sees in the gloomy half-light FIGURES HANGING FROM THE WALLS. His MEN, CRUCIFIED, FLAYED, IMPALED all around. The REAPER RISES and slowly advances on Kane. He moves wi a savage, predatory grace. Beautiful and menacing.

dialogues.speaker: REAPER
dialogues.text: Your time is over Kane. Your deal is done. I have been sent to claim His prize.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 8

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I made no deal.

dialogues.speaker: REAPER
dialogues.text: When you killed your first innocent in greed and lust; you made your pact with Him. Kane struggles to his feet again.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I am a soldier. I killed only...

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: Once more the sound is like a hammer blow, knocking Kane his hands and knees.

dialogues.speaker: REAPER
dialogues.text: You are a butcher! Revelling in the fear and torment you brought with you!

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: (quietly) No...

dialogues.speaker: REAPER, (CONT)
dialogues.text: And were you not rewarded? With power? With wealth? with fame? Everything you desired. As the spectre finally stands over him, Kane looks up and stares into the abyss of the shadow’s face; there are burning eyes deep within, a ghastly predatory face that shifts and twists with each word.

dialogues.speaker: REAPER
dialogues.text: You know who I serve? Kane tries to catch his breath. His world is spinning as realises just what he is facing.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: You... you cannot take my soul.

dialogues.speaker: REAPER
dialogues.text: You have already lost it. Bow your head before me! Kane sees now, in the Demon’s hand, A SWORD. A blade of seething molten metal. Runes and patterns flow across its surface.

dialogues.speaker: REAPER
dialogues.text: You are damned.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 9 Defeated, Kane does, slowly, bow his head. The Reaper raises the sword above him, preparing to strike the death blow. It sweeps down with incredible force only to be met by... ...KANE’S TWO SWORDS BLOCKING its path. Kane rises to his feet. Teeth gritted, eyes blazing.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Tell your master I will not be going to Hell. Even in the face of this pure evil Kane will not be defeated. He stares into the abyss once more; unflinching though still full of fear now.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: The Lord protects me. Kane paries another sweeping thrusts but the burning blad slices through his rapier.

dialogues.speaker: REAPER
dialogues.text: Fool! He does not want you. You are damned. Kane blocks a return thrust which destroys his cutlass. Unarmed now, Kane slowly backs away as the Reaper advance on him again. There’s nowhere for him to go...

dialogues.speaker: REAPER
dialogues.text: On your knees!

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Never! I will never give myself to you! Kane charges at the HUGE STAINED GLASS WINDOW and smashes through an image of Demons and Angels, locked in eternal conflict. The glass shatters, revealing the burning city and the night sky beyond but nothing below apart from the sea crashing onto jagged rocks hundreds of feet beneath. With a desolate cry, Kane plummets down into the void wit the words of the Devil ringing in his ears.

dialogues.speaker: REAPER
dialogues.text: You cannot escape us. Wherever you go, we will find you...Your soul is lost.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO BLACK
dialogues.text: Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 19 A TERRIBLE SCREAM against the blackness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ISOLATED GREY STONE MONASTERY on a windswept hillside. The first pale splashes of a chill, silver dawn bring little hope for the day to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TwO MONKS in their heavy hooded robes carry a tray of wat and bread along the cloisters of an open courtyard. Their breath steams around them. Other MONKS go silently about their business.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MONK
dialogues.text: How long has he been here?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MONK
dialogues.text: Nearly a year.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MONK
dialogues.text: A year? Master, I do not understand why we serve this man.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MONK
dialogues.text: We do not serve him. He sought sanctuary here and that is what we offer. Are you, a novice, to judge him? They stop outside a door.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MONK
dialogues.text: I hear his screams in the night.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MONK
dialogues.text: We all do. You might scream too if you’d seen what he has.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MONK
dialogues.text: (awed) Then what they say about him is true. The older monk casts a withering eye on the novice.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MONK
dialogues.text: What do they say Thomas?  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett an A nervous pause. The young monk is not sure he should eve say this out loud.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MONK
dialogues.text: That... he met... that... Satan himself came for his soul but he would not relinquish it. That his body is marked with runes and spells to keep him from the sight of the Dark One.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MONK
dialogues.text: A lesser man would be out of his mind by now but Kane... he is unlike any other. The older monk knocks on Kane’s door. INT. KANE’S MONASTIC CELL - CONT 8 The KNOCK on Kane’s door is followed by a gentle creaking as it opens slowly. The two monks respectfully enter the gloomy room as Kane remains silent but watchful in his co

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MONK
dialogues.text: Solomon? A voice comes from a dark corner.

dialogues.speaker: KANE 0/S
dialogues.text: Brother Fletcher; how does the day find you?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MONK
dialogues.text: As the Lord intended; cold of bone and stiff of joint. We have a little breakfast for you.

dialogues.speaker: KANE 0/S
dialogues.text: Who is this novice?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MONK
dialogues.text: He joined us only a few days ago. Kane levers himself to the edge of his bed and into the flickering amber light of a candle. The Kane of now is a man of small gestures and quiet, almost diffident talk - the brash, aggressive buccaneer of before has long since vanished. He has aged. His hair is longer, a stubbly bear is flecked with grey hair. His eyes are haunted. The YOUNG NOVICE draws breath sharply as he notices Kane’ NAKED TORSO. Kane’s' body has been marked with elaborate cuts and tattoos. Some fresh, others old and scarred over his skin is a text of its own.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 42 The walls of the room itself are covered in similar WRITI and SYMBOLS. Runes, hexes, spells and text have been carved or painted onto the walls. There are dozens of books and scrolls around the room. Religious and spiritua texts lie alongside books on witchcraft and sorcery.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MONK
dialogues.text: (stunned) Your body...

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MONK
dialogues.text: Still your tongue! (to Kane) Forgive him Solomon, he is young.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: (to the novice) Didn’t you know; I am a marked man? Thomas cannot help but stare.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MONK
dialogues.text: Do they really... protect you from...

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT 0/S
dialogues.text: Mind who you name in this holy place, novice! A SHADOW falls across the open doorway. They turn to see the ABBOT. Both monks bow their heads as the Abbot enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: Leave us. The monks hurry out as the Abbot closes the door behind them. He is an elderly man; stern and devout but not unkind. He scrutinizes the room, taking in the desecratio around him. He eyes Kane silently.

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: Once again we heard your cries at matins.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean to disturb your prayers. My dreams haunt me, even here.

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: You would do well to listen to what they tell you.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: They tell me I am damned.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 13 The Abbot examines the books and texts on a table. He is not pleased by what he sees; a Bible with scribblings and notes over the text. Other books, clearly full of magic a pagan spells.

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: And yet you still defile our sacred text. And these others; such dark works.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: They are just books Abbot.

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: If you believed words had no power you would never have corrupted your own flesh so. Men have been burned for less.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I am no heretic.

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: I know that my son but these are not times of tolerance. If someone were to ever find out that we harboured you there would be... questions. Kane climbs from the bed and gathers his papers together, returning them to his wooden chest and closing the lid.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Who would know? I live here in solitude; I have renounced violence; given up my power. Given my wealth to the church.

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: And we are grateful for all your gifts to us. (about the books) You don’t need this witchcraft to hide from evil; God protects his own.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: But I am not one of God’s own am I? But how can I redeemed myself in His eyes, when I know the servants of darkness are searching for me? Kane falls silent. The Abbot sits.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 14

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: Solomon, these months you have been here, I have felt a shadow growing over us all. And when I prayed for guidance I (a beat) I do not see a way for you to remain. (a long pause) You must leave us.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Leave? No.

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: I am sorry.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Please Abbot, this is sanctuary. But Kane sees the resolve in the Abbot’s face.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Where can I go?

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: Go home.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: You are of noble birth; I know you have lands in the west.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: Solomon I...

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I cannot return home.

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: Nor can you remain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High winds sweep rain horizontally against the stone wall of the monastery as the GATES OPEN.  10 14 12 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 418 Kane is standing there. Long staff in his hand, hat pulle low and heavy wool cloak wrapped about him. Just a few bags of his personal possessions are slung over his shoulder. Several MONKS are by the gate. One of them hands him a small parcel of food. They watch silently and CROSS THEMSELVES as he steps over the threshold and into the unknown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching from a high window, the ABBOT and the OLDER MONK see Kane set out.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MONK
dialogues.text: Are you doing right by sending him back into the world?

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: My dreams said he must be sent from here. I listen to what I am told. The Abbot watches Kane stride away.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MONK
dialogues.text: Can Kane bring anything but destruction and pain?

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: Perhaps that is what is needed in these darkening times. He wants redemption for his sins; there are many paths to God, not all of them peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KANE makes his way across the lonely hills and valleys of this desolate part of the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In driving rain, KANE passes by a TINY GROUP OF NEARLY DERELICT HOUSES. A MOTHER wails in distress as the FATHER digs GRAVES for several dead children wrapped in cloth at their feet. The mother watches Kane pass with dead eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MIX TO
dialogues.text: 13 14 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DRIVING RAIN has eased. The landscape clothed in dank fog. It fills the hollows and clings to the rocks. The cold settles into Kane’s bones as he makes his way across open ground. From behind him, he hears the SOUND of a WAGON rattling towards him. He turns to see it emerge like a vast ghost through the fog. It’s a FAMILY driving their covered wago Kane steps out of their way to allow them to pass. The DRIVER nods and slows his wagon. A young BOY looks at Kane from the back of the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Can we offer you a ride pilgrim? These roads ahead should not be travelled alone.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: My thanks friend but no.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: As you wish. God be with you. The driver urges his horses onwards and soon he and his family are swallowed in the mist once again. Kane hefts his bags and settles into his stride, down the path. Up ahead the fog suddenly seems to darken as the tree lin of a FOREST comes into view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thicker fog in these trees now. The damp dripping from th branches and the cold clinging to Kane’s woollen cape. Th trees seem to press in on him. A flock of birds taking flight noisily sets him on edge. He comes to a fork in the path and stops to consider. A creaking in the trees leads him to look up and see FOUR HUMAN CORPSES swing from several branches in the trees. A hanging by nooses, some with their INNARDS DRAWN OUT. KANE chooses a path and presses on.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 15 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett a7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in the depths of the ancient forest, KANE has set himself a small camp to the side of the track. A tiny fir is flickering, heating water as he chews some bread. A MOVEMENT AMONG THE TREES draws his attention, he sits u attentively but sees nothing. Then from behind him, A KNIFE IS PRESSED TO HIS THROAT.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE 0/S
dialogues.text: Move and you die. Kane is forced to his feet by a heavy-set, SKINHEAD THIEF who whistles to his TWO COMPANIONS who are lurking in the undergrowth. One is heavily TATTOOED whilst the other is massively built with a HEAVY, BRAIDED BEARD. They are a feral and dangerous group and enjoying their brutal work.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I want no trouble. BEARD SMASHES Kane in the stomach with a heavy cudgel. Ka doubles and falls to the ground, coughing.

dialogues.speaker: BEARD
dialogues.text: Too bad. You’ve already got it. They begin to search through his bags. There’s almost nothing of interest or value. BEARD empties Kane’s bag of scrolls and books. The few coins, some food and other ite are taken. The thieves are not happy.

dialogues.speaker: BEARD
dialogues.text: He’s got nothing. You a priest?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: A traveller.

dialogues.speaker: BEARD
dialogues.text: Travelling where?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Nowhere. Just take what you want.

dialogues.speaker: BEARD
dialogues.text: Don’t worry pilgrim, we will. Kane keeps his head down. TATTOO stares at the scrolls.

dialogues.speaker: TATTOO
dialogues.text: Look at these. I say he’s a sorcerer, See here; these is magical symbols.  16 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 18 Tattoo grabs Kane by the hair and drags him to the fire.

dialogues.speaker: TATTOO
dialogues.text: Should we burn you for a witch? Tattoo’s companions cheer him on as he pushes Kane’s face near to the flames. Kane does not fight but resists and n matter how hard Tattoo pushes he cannot make Kane move. Finally Kane yanks his head free and stares hard into Tattoo’s eyes. The thief flinches from the deadly look

dialogues.speaker: TATTOO
dialogues.text: There’s murder in your eyes traveller. Would you kill me?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TATTOO
dialogues.text: You won’t kill the men who steal from you?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I will not fight another man. SKINHEAD slaps Kane, sends him reeling back. Kane slowly climbs to his feet. The robbers laugh.

dialogues.speaker: SKINHEAD
dialogues.text: You worthless coward. Fight me.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I will not fight you. I have renounced violence.

dialogues.speaker: BEARD
dialogues.text: We haven't. BEARD SMASHES KANE ACROSS THE HEAD with his wooden cudgel

dialogues.speaker: STERN VOICE V/O
dialogues.text: You will do as I say boy! Through the darkness STERN MAN’S FACE swims into view through the smoke and mist of Kane’s memory. He looms dow onto Kane. This is his FATHER...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOURTEEN YEAR OLD SOLOMON KANE is standing defiantly befo his father’s high chair at the head of the Great Hall of his castle home. Various SERVANTS and HANGERS-ON mill about but they are trying to avoid the conflict that is raging between father and son.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 19

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: No! KANE’S FATHER You are the second son and Marcus is my heir. Your brother will be master of these lands on my death.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Marcus is a brute and... KANE’S FATHER (talking him down) ...And you, you will join the church as is tradition.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I do not wish to be a priest; I want to go to sea. KANE’S FATHER What you want is of no importance Solomon! I have arranged with Father Simnal for you to accompany him to the abbey. At his father’s signal, FATHER SIMNAL who has been sittin nearby, steps up and nods politely to Kane.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I have no interest in the church or its teachings. I will not go. KANE’S FATHER Then you will have nothing. I will cut you off. You will be a landless vagrant. Is that what you want? Kane turns from his father and storms out. KANE’S FATHER If you walk out now, you may never return. Do not defy me. His Father’s words are ringing in young Kane’s ears as he flings back the doors to the great hall. And there, suddenly, looming before him is the DEVIL’S REAPER - BURNING SWORD in hand. The Demon swings the blad and CUTS KANE DOWN even as Kane screams out in pain and fear...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 17 18 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 20

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KANE wakes with a sudden cry to find a YOUNG WOMAN leanin over him, concerned. Talking gently, soothing...

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Be calm...be calm Sir. You are safe. (calling off) Father! Kane tries to speak but he’s delirious and confused. His face is bloodied and swollen; his body bruised and stiff.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Here...Take a little water. But Kane fades back into unconsciousness again. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH V/O
dialogues.text: You are safe here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beneath a threatening sky and with the imposing grandeur AXMOUTH CASTLE in the distance YOUNG KANE wanders the windswept sea cliffs away from his home. He has his travelling bags slung over his shoulder, clearly ready fo the road. The open ocean sweeps out in front to the distant horizon A few TALL SHIPS OF THE NAVY cruise past. Solomon watches them, envious as DISTANT SHOUTS from the crew drift to hi Then he hears a SUDDEN, SHARP SCREAM from nearby. He drop his bags and rushes round a corner to see a very tall, POWERFUL YOUNG MAN overpowering a PRETTY YOUNG GIRL. He’s tearing at her clothes, clearly trying to rape her KANE DRAWS A SHORT KNIFE from his belt and rushes forward grabbing the youth and pulling him back...

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Stop! ...,only to halt, stunned, when the older youth turns on him.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Marcus...  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 2a

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: (mocking) Little brother. I heard you had run away. Fleeing the life of a holy man.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Marcus, you must not do this. (to the girl) Sarah, are you hurt?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Solomon he was trying to... Marcus slaps the girl to silence.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Quiet! I gave you no permission to speak. (to Kane) This is not your concern, Solomon. Be on your way. Kane advances on Marcus and pulls Sarah from his grasp.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: No! Let her go. Sarah, run. Go now! Sarah races away. Kane squares up to his brother. Marcus is immense in stature, far taller and more powerfully bui than his whip-thin younger brother

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t get between a master and his pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Is that how it’s going to be when you are Lord here; nothing but greed and cruelty?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: (about Kane’s knife) What were you going to do with that little toothpick?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Teach you some humility to accompany your power.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I don’t think you’re the one to teach me anything little brother Marcus, suddenly, grabs Kane’s arm, twists it hard and snatches the knife from him.  19 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 22 He presses it to his Kane’s throat, drawing a little bloo Whispering savagely in his brother’s ear.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I am the first-born; I am the heir and that means I am your master too. You will never be anything more than a coward, fleeing your duty. Take your bags and leave this land. Marcus pushes Kane away. In fury, Kane turns and shoves h brother back towards the cliff edge. Caught by surprise Marcus stumbles back and trips ona rock... ...With a cry he TOPPLES BACKWARDS, OVER THE EDGE OF THE CLIFF. Kane desperately reaches for Marcus’s flailing hand but cannot save him.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Brother!!! Save me! He falls... Kane scrambles to the edge only to see, fifty feet below, the SHATTERED BODY OF HIS BROTHER, still twitching, on th rocks below. His head has been crushed in, his jaw partly torn away. All Kane can see through the mask of blood on his brother destroyed face are his eyes, staring, furiously back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time Kane wakes in slow silence. No screaming, just muted sadness and pain as he opens his bleary eyes onto t wagon. A twelve year old boy, SAMUEL, is looking through some ba nearby. He is working silently and doesn’t notice Kane is awake and watching him.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Boy... Samuel turns and yells in fear and scrambles out of the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL 0/S
dialogues.text: (yelling) He’s awake! Father! That man he’s awake!  20 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 23 Kane tries to right himself but hasn’t the energy. He groans in pain. The flaps of the wagon cover are drawn back. Faces are silhouetted against the daylight that pours in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young woman, MEREDITH, is holding Kane’s head as she puts a flask to his lips. He drinks. Finally finds his voice.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: (faintly) Who...are you? The man by Meredith’s side is WILLIAM CROWTHORN. In his 50’s, he has an air solemn kindness and gentle good humou about him. He’s dressed in the simple, DARK CLOTHES OF A PURITAN, as are all his family. Meredith mops Kane’s brow.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: (to her father) He is still fevered Father.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It has broken. He will be well. (to Kane) Sir, my name is William Crowthorn. This is my daughter Meredith. And you met, quite briefly, my son Samuel. My eldest, Edward, is driving this wagon and my wife Katherine is outside also. Samuel peers in nervously from outside.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Where are you taking me?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: We prayed for you. Meredith has nursed you these past days. All of us have spent time at you side. Kane tries to rise again. He’s wounded and weak but fighting.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Where are you taking me?  21 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 24

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: There are many evils on this road but we are not among them. You are safe and on the road heading west to Plymouth.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Plymouth?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: We’re bound for the New World. Kane studies the man for a moment

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I know you. You offered me a ride.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I should have accepted.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: True enough. You took quite some beating but in a few days, the Lord willing, you will be fit once more. (calling out) Edward, pull over now. We’1l make camp for the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The COVERED CART is driven by EDWARD, William’s eldest so and a serious young man in his mid 20’s. Though all the family are dressed as Puritans, only Edward wears the dog collar and garb of a PRIEST. Beside him on the bench is William’s wife, KATHERINE; a bright and homely woman in her 50’s. SAMUEL is walking besides the cart, swatting the long grass with a stick. EDWARD guides the cart to some open ground beside a cryst clear river. It is an idyllic spot in a picturesque valley.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 22 23 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 28

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEREDITH and KATHERINE are gathering together cooking utensils and food stuff for the evening meal. WILLIAM and EDWARD are preparing a covered area for sleeping by the wagon. Young SAMUEL is exploring nearby.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Don’t stray too far Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Samuel; water the horses. (Samuel ignores him) Samuel!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Samuel! Edward has given you a task; set to it. Reluctantly and muttering, Samuel unhitches the horses an lead them to the river KANE steps out of the wagon, still a little unsteady. Katherine is surprised to see him.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Master Kane, you should be resting.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I can hardly repay your hospitality by being idle Mistress Crowthorn. Allow me a moment to wash and then I’1l help as I can. Katherine watches as Kane limps down towards the water’s edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KANE kneels beside the waters. Some way along from him SAMUEL supervises the horses as they drink. He eyes Kane nervously.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: What is your name boy? Samuel doesn’t reply.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Don’t fear me. What is your name?  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 26 MEREDITH comes to the river, she stops nearby Kane and begins to fill a water-skin.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Your little brother has lost his tongue I think.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Remember your manners with our guest Samuel. Kane pulls his torn and blood-stained shirt off to reveal his bruised body - along with the tattoos and scars. Meredith is shocked by what she sees. Kane notices. Samue too is astounded by the marks and patterns on Kane’s body

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: How...What are they?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: These? They are the story of my life. See? Meredith comes a little nearer, fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Some are of my own making; these marks and symbols here.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: What do they mean?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: They are for... protection. Others, here, are wounds.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: How were you hurt? Kane points to a deep scar on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I’ve been shot, stabbed and beaten more times than I recall. This here, was a spear thrust by a tribesman of Africa.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Africa? You were at sea?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I was a Captain. Samuel suddenly comes alive with interest.  24 25 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett ar

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: You were a sea Captain!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KANE sits with the rest of the FAMILY around the camp fir their heads are bowed in prayer as EDWARD reads from a prayer book.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Holy Lord, I have sinned times without number, and been guilty of pride and unbelief... Kane lifts his head at these pointedly accurate words and looks at the family caught in the flickering firelight. H catches Meredith looking too but, embarrassed, she quickl closes her eyes again.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT)
dialogues.text: ...of failure to find Thy mind in Thy Word, of neglect to seek Thee in my daily life....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all eating hungrily now. The simple stew has bee well received.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: This is a fine meal Mistress Crowthorn; my thanks.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: My Katherine can make a meal from anything. Leather shoes and nettles one time wasn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: It was not!

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: It tasted like it. The family laugh at this.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Samuel tells us you were the Captain of a ship.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 28

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I commanded the Queen’s frigate, Tiercel.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Did you fight the Spanish?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I have fought everyone at some time. Off The Main, the Caribbean, the frozen north; places not on any map.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: The Holy Land?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Yes Edward; I fought the Muslims beneath the walls of Jerusalem itself.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: What a life you have led. It must have been so exciting.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: You think a life devoted to violence and bloodshed is so admirable?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Don’t be foolish Edward.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I fought in our own holy wars under King Henry many years ago. The taking of men’s lives is hard no matter what their faith, don’t you agree Solomon? Kane chooses his words carefully.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: For many, yes. But I confess William, I had a particular gift for it. I was never more at home than in battle.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Then how did you allow those robbers to beat you so badly?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Edward that is rude.  26 KANE appears from out of the shadows fumbles ineffectually for a cudgel. Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 29

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: But it is a good question. Edward, I have sworn an oath never to harm another man. I will not fight.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Not at all?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: But what if you meet more bad men?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: If the Lord sees fit to put them in my way then that is as it must be.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Remember Samuel, it was the Lord who also saw fit to put us in Captain Kane’s path.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Nothing happens without a reason: There is a plan for us all.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I’m a friend.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (laughing at himself) I’d be of little use if you were not, my fighting days are long gone. Could you not sleep?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: My dreams often disturb me. (a beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 26 A bright moon shines over the valley. All seems peaceful the camp slumbers. WILLIAM is on watch by the dying fire. He’s looking at a map and smoking a pipe. startling William who  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 30 KANE(cont 'd) I’d be happy to take watch while you rest, William.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No, it is my task alone to watch over my family. But you’re welcome to sit with me. Kane settles beside William. They sit for a time, enjoyin the flickering warmth of the nearby fire.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: You are blessed to have such a family.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I know. See? Williams takes a LOCKET from his neck and opens it for Ka to see. Inside are PORTRAITS OF KATHERINE and MEREDITH.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: The two most beautiful women in this world. My family is everything to me. Do you have kin?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I had a brother... but that was a lifetime ago.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I have lost loved ones; to plague, to persecution and bigotry. Edward, lost his wife and child. William falls silent in contemplation.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: So you sail for America.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: We do. It is a new start in a New World. I sold every possession we had to pay for this passage. You might consider journeying with us. Kane falls into silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: William let me be honest, so you know who you have taken in; I did not lie when I said killing was my great gift, above all others. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett an KANE(cont 'd) My cruelty and murderous nature were famed. I am - I was - an evil man. William studies Kane for a moment and thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: We have all sinned because we are all human.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: But my soul is damned. Satan’s creatures will take me should I stray from the path of peace. (a beat) I will understand if I am no longer welcome here.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You are welcome Solomon. (lightening the tone) If only because I need a better navigator than myself to read this fool map. I could be leading us to Portsmouth not Plymouth for all I know. Here, take a look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FAMILY make their way along a dirt track, the wagon bouncing around as it hits ruts and potholes. KANE - his bruised face far less noticeable now - walks a the head with the horses. EDWARD, as usual, is driving th cart. MEREDITH sits at his side sewing some material.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Captain Kane. Kane drops back to see her. She hands TROUSERS.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Miss Meredith; how can I be of service?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: I made some clothes for you as your others were so torn. him down a dark PURITAN TUNIC, SHIRT and Kane is touched by this.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I shall wear them with pride.  28 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 32 SAMUEL is thrashing at the undergrowth nearby with a stic startling the horses a little.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Hold off on that wanton destruction Samuel. Samuel gives Edward a pointed stare and carries on.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Do as Edward says Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Why? He’s not Father. I don’t have to do what he says.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Samuel!

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: You know, you should listen to your elder brother Sam. Samuel halts his whipping. Kane nods approvingly at the boy, much to Samuel’s delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAMUEL walks beside KANE now, matching his easy stride. WILLIAM and KATHERINE are up ahead, walking hand in hand. Kane finishes pulling on the clothes Meredith made. He is dressed in their own Puritan fashion now and models it fo Meredith who is picking herbs and flowers nearby.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Do I meet with your approval?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Finally you are respectable. He bows to her. She giggles. Edward is less than impresse

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Our clothes are not for fashion or vanity Captain Kane; through them we show our dedication to God. With a courteous nod, Kane acknowledges his understanding of this fact. Though he does share a quick smile with Meredith - who can barely hold back a giggle - as they wa on.  29 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel still keeping pace with Kane.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Are you going to come America with us?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I don’t think so Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: You are hoping to make a new life; I need to undo my old one.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Those men who hurt you, you could have beaten them if you wanted, couldn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: (quietly) There was a time I’d have cut their still-beating hearts from their chests. Samuel is a little taken aback by this statement. He take a moment to regroup then shrugs it off and dances around Kane holding his stick like a sword.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Would you fight me?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: (laughing) If you continue with your questions I might.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Leave Captain Kane alone. Samuel pokes Kane with his stick.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me what to do Edward. (to Kane) Fight me. Pokes Kane again.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I have no cause to fight you.  30 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 34 Samuel makes a sudden dash to grab Meredith. She screams half annoyed, half playful.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Samuel, stop it!

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Now you have a reason! To save this beautiful maiden from me!

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: (playing along) Oh Solomon! Save me! Help!

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Stop, you’1l scare the horses. Joining into the spirit of it all Kane swipes up a stick from the side of the road. Jokingly he parries Samuel’s thrust.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: I knew it. I knew you would fight if you had to. Meredith laughs and even Edward manages a gentle smile at this.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: You’re quite a foe Samuel but I’1l fight to save this beauty. WILLIAM and KATHERINE watch contentedly. Then the wagon come around a corner to a VILLAGE to find. ...BODIES lying twisted in the middle of the road. The ti VILLAGE beyond IS IN RUINS - many of the houses still burning, others just blackened frames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KANE, WILLIAM and EDWARD are looking at DOZENS OF CORPSES scattered around the village. CROWS line the trees nearby waiting to move in. The air of death and menace hangs heavy. A little way back MEREDITH, KATHERINE and SAMUEL wait uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Who could have done this? Kane studies the bodies. Men, women and children are twisted in agonized forms.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 38 Some seem to have been burned, skin peeled away. ALL THEI EYES ARE BURNED FROM THEIR SKULLS, leaving hollow, empty sockets.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: The Devil has been here. Edward drops to his knees and starts to pray.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Holy Father... Katherine, Meredith and Samuel press near

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Keep back! Kane looks around.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Not the Devil....a witch. There is a pyre in the centre of the village square with stake in the centre. It has been partly consumed by flame

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: There was a witch burning here but the creature broke free. William turns over a horribly disfigured body. It is a ma dressed in the classic dark clothes of a WITCHFINDER, the charred remnants of a bible are in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Dear Lord, this is the witchfinder general. If he is dead...

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: We must go.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: We can’t just leave these people for carrion.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: There’s nothing we can do for them. Kane holds William’s steady gaze.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: We must bury them as Christians.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 31 32 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 36

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KANE, sweating and filthy, is finishing digging a shallow grave as EDWARD and WILLIAM lower a body into another nearby. There are a handful of others graves dotted about each with a wooden cross marking it. KATHERINE is making the wooden crosses nearby. SAMUEL watches uneasily from the wagon in the distance whilst everyone else is involved in the unsavory task. Kane eyes the setting sun nervously. MEREDITH approaches over the rough ground and offers him a cup of water. He drinks thirstily.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Thank you. She looks at him for a moment and he catches her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Your...your wounds are healing well.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I never thanked you for your care.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: There is no need to thank me. Now both stand amongst the graves, unsure what to say nex

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE 0/S
dialogues.text: I need more wood for these crosses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEREDITH is AT THE EDGE OF THE VILLAGE SQUARE now, gathering up pieces of wood for the crosses. As she reaches for some, she notices TWO BODIES nearby. The BODY OF A WOMAN TWITCHES with some slight movement. Meredith makes to shout out to her brother and father who are carrying another corpse to the graves some yards away but then the body moves again. She approaches the corpse. Inch by inch reaching out a ha to turn the corpse over...  33 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 37 ...a@ YOUNG GIRL, no more than 8 years old, is clinging t the body of her mother. This blood stained and ragged child stares up at Meredith with terrified eyes and unleashes a TERRIFIED SCREAM that echoes across the whole village....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHILD sits between MEREDITH and KATHERINE, wrapped in blanket and drinking some warm broth. The rest of the family are sitting around the FIRE. KANE is a little way off, nervously watching the gathering darkness.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Can you tell us what happened child? It takes a moment for the child to find her voice. When s does it is so soft as to be barely audible but the terrib story is clear enough.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (quietly) The grown-ups said there was a witch in the woods. She’d been taking cattle and children. My brother died. Meredith comforts the girl as she draws breath to continu haltingly...

dialogues.speaker: GIRL, (CONT)
dialogues.text: ... They called that man, the Witchfinder. He said that the witches and devils were growing more powerful than ever before. That something had happened to give them strength. But still, he trapped the witch and sentenced her to be burned at the stake. They all came to watch her die in the fire but... when they set the flames... It didn’t hurt her. She laughed and said... she said that a great sorcerer had opened the gate to Hell and that all the devil’s children were free. And then...then she killed them all. Only the crackle of the wood on the fire breaks the silen now.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 38

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: (quietly) We should pray. The family bow their heads. Kane doesn’t. He watches the girl.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I’m tired.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Just a moment more.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (suddenly angry) I don’t want to! (soft again) I’m so tired, please.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Of course you are, you poor thing. Let’s find a place for you to sleep. As Meredith helps the girl to her feet, Kane stalks over.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Edward, I think the child should have your cross for protection tonight. Would you mind? The child watches Kane.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Of course not - here. He hands Kane the silver CROSS from around his own neck Kane takes it and slowly approaches the girl. He kneels before her.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: If you wear this, it will help keep you safe tonight. The girls eyes the silver cross as it catches the red firelight.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I don’t want to.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: It will help.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: No.  34 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 39

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Just let me... (reaching for her) ...put it around you neck.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Solomon, stop it. Can’t you see she’s frightened? Suddenly Kane lunges for her violently. He grabs her...

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Solomon, no! ...and press the crucifix into the child’s flesh. Instantly the CHILD SCREAMS as the METAL BURNS HER SKIN. She starts to howl and snarl in Kane’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Dear god what have you done?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: This is her! This is the witch! The LITTLE GIRL NOW HAS TRANSFORMED in Kane’s arms. A fou ancient and yet ferocious looking creature with a twisted snarling face, sharp teeth and long nails that tear at hi She is so strong he cannot hold her.

dialogues.speaker: WITCH
dialogues.text: Solomon Kane! Solomon Kane! Your Master awaits his pleasure with you. I’ll be there too, in the Pit! The gates of hell are open for you Kane. And suddenly she tears herself from Kane’s arms and FLIES INTO THE AIR and away into the night. They can hear her cackling, screaming laughter echo into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KANE and the FAMILY are travelling in silence along the rutted back roads of southern England. They have clearly been travelling all night and are exhausted. As they approach a fork in the dirt road they hear the sound of many voices approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 49 A DOZEN or so PEASANTS appear from around a bend in the road ahead. Some are bloody and beaten - it is cle they are DESPERATE REFUGEES of some kind. William tries to talk to the first few but they pass him without stopping. Finally a

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What is wrong? Tell me! PRIEST rushes by.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Tell me what has happened? Is it the witch?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: A witch? I wish it was. No, these are Raiders... Dear God such terrible, cruel men. Join them or perish, they said. When we fought back but it was a massacre. Dear Lord...they seem possessed of some terrible evil. Turn back while you can or they’1l have you for their slaves! He pushes William aside and rushes on with the tide of refugees.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: What will we do?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: We must turn back.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: This is the only road to Plymouth - how else will we make the ship? We must go on, find another way.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Please Father...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Our future is in the New World.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: William, you must not continue. Can’t you feel it? There is something evil gathering in the west. Go back.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett an

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: There’s nothing for us to go back to. Our only way is ahead, to get to the ship. Can you help me? KANE takes a MAP from the saddle of one of the horses. He studies it for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Then this road... (showing the map) ...it takes us south through these forests and we can find a way west again, here.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: How can you be sure? We should turn back Father. Perhaps wait a time.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Edward’s right. It’s too dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Trust me. I can lead you.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: You can get us through?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: If it is in my powers, I’1l get you to your vessel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone now in the empty countryside the wagon passes out o the open landscape and into the forest

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deep shadows under the thick canopy. Strange noises echo through the trees but there is no signs of life.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Are you sure this is the safest way?  37 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 42

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: There is no safe way but if these raiders are taking slaves and looting villages they’1l hunt in the populated areas north of here. We may slip past them unseen. But these forests are not without their dangers. Be wary.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: What kind of dangers?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Captain Kane means animals and suchlike. Now quiet. The cart and horses rattles along slowly. The passengers looking nervously about them. They enter an open glade in the forest. Before them are SOME RUINS, half overgrown by the forest

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: We’11 make camp here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very subdued group make camp. WILLIAM is setting a fire as SAMUEL gathers wood. KANE emerges from a forest path nearby.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I see no signs of life in either direction, we should be safe. But William, set no fire tonight, it might attract unwanted attention. William stops lighting the fire.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I’ll take first watch - if that is all right with you William?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: MIX TO
dialogues.text: 38 39 40 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 43

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark night with the moon covered by heavy clouds. Sheet lightning ripples within them, thunder rumbles in the distance. But the camp is peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SOLOMON’S TENT - DAWN 39 KANE snaps awake to find SAMUEL’S hand urgently shaking him. The SOUND OF RAIN is loud on the canvas.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Solomon. Solomon...Wake up.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: I heard something in the trees. Immediately Kane is up and heading out the tent.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn mist hangs amongst the trees. Branches drip water as the RAIN hammers down through the foliage. KANE stalks through the undergrowth until he sees MOVEMEN through the trees on the other side of a small RIVER. A SUDDEN SOUND behind him, makes him turn sharply. It’s just SAMUEL, trying to keep up. Kane urgently waves him away but the young man is determined to be with Kane.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: (hissing) Be silent Samuel, this is no game. Together they advance until they see more clearly... ...@ PARTY OF MARAUDERS ON HORSEBACK. They are a grotesqu bunch with scarred and twisted faces. All have an ARCANE MAGICAL INSIGNIA on their torn and shredded leathers and rough chain mail. Some even have it branded into their flesh.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: What are they Solomon?  41 42 43 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 44

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: They must be the Raiders we heard of (hushed, urgent) Listen to me; Go back to the camp, quietly wake them and tell your father we are to move out immediately. Go! Go! Samuel turns and hurries back the way they came. Kane continues his silent advance on the marauders. He se now that they have CAGES HALF FILLED WITH DESPERATE PEOPL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAMUEL running as fast as he can back to the CAMP. He stops dead when he sees... ... THERE ARE RAIDERS ALREADY THERE. Six brutal looking m dragging WILLIAM, KATHERINE, EDWARD and MEREDITH from the tents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLIAM and EDWARD are already bloody and beaten. MEREDIT fights like a wild cat but she is punched and thrown to t ground. Even in the face of the chaos and violence William is trying to keep everyone calm. Offering comfort and suppor to his frightened family as he’s being beaten down into t mud.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (to the attackers) Here, take what you want; it’s yours. (reaching for Meredith) Everything will be all right Meredith. Edward don’t try and fight them.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Where’s Samuel? Samuel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silently SAMUEL backs away and right into...  44 46 47 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 48 ...A RAIDER who steps from behind a tree and grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL 0/S
dialogues.text: Solomon! Solomon! ! KANE, hearing SAMUEL’S CRY, turns - and without caring about being seen now - RACES BACK ALONG THE FOREST PATH.:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KANE blasting through the trees, heading back to the camp Branches whip against him, thorns cutting, rain pouring down... but he ignores it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RAIDERS are destroying the camp. Setting fire to possessions, taking the horses for their own. Watching it all is the OVERLORD. He takes no part in thes activities but sits motionless on a MASSIVE BLACK HORSE. The Overlord is a HUGE FIGURE, ENCASED IN LEATHER ARMOUR, his face entirely covered by a grotesque MASK, huge sword hanging at his waist. It’s almost as if he is directing h men silently simply by sheer force of will. MEREDITH is struggling against her CAPTORS. She hits him but he throws her to the ground. Crouching over her, he tears at her clothes, his intentions clear. WILLIAM and KATHERINE watch in horror. SAMUEL scrambles t them.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Leave her! Please... EDWARD, struggles free from his captor and rises to her defence...

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Take your hands off her! He hits the attacker with all his strength but it makes n difference. Another raider beats Edward to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: KANE 0/S
dialogues.text: No!!  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 46 The RAIDERS turn at this new voice. Many hands on the hil of vicious SWORDS but there is just one man there. KANE is standing at the edge of the clearing, breathless and desperate.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Stop! The OVERLORD seems to be watching this newcomer intently. He looks to one of this raiders, the one with the EYE- PATCH, and nods slowly. EYE-PATCH strides forward, snatching Samuel away from his mother and dragging him along as he advances on Kane. He takes a huge, serrated knife from his belt and presses it to the boys’ throat. The OVERLORD watches all this calmly. Kane prepares himself as the Raider stops a few yards in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I am unarmed. Wiping the rain from his face, Kane sizes up the raider. He’s desperately trying to work out how to diffuse the situation.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: These people... Listen to me; these people, they’re good people. Christians. Devout people. They’re no threat.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Kill him, Solomon. Kill them all.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No Samuel. Solomon don’t... Samuel struggles against his captor. Fighting furiously. The other raiders are advancing slowly on Kane.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Samuel, don’t struggle. He’1l let you go if you don’t do anything. (to Eye-Patch) Won’t you? They have no money. What else can they give you? (a sudden thought) You want slaves? Take me. I’m strong; better than these people.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett aT

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: I know you can do it Solomon. Kill him. Cut his heart out!

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Samuel silence! Kane’s eyes flick over to the silent, OVERLORD waiting nearby. The figure raises his arm and clenches his fist and then suddenly... ...The Eye-Patch Raider starts to shake and jerk as if something is moving within him. His single eye, turns as black as congealed blood. The VOICE that comes from Eye-Patch is a rumbling growl that fills the forest. A little BLOOD DRIBBLES FROM HIS MOUTH as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: EYE-PATCH
dialogues.text: Kill me, can you?

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: No...I am a man of peace; I offer no resistance. Take me. Do not harm them.

dialogues.speaker: EYE-PATCH
dialogues.text: (shaking the boy) This boy... ...this child has more heart than any of you. He’s the only man here.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: (placating) Listen to me.... Eye-Patch shifts his grip on the knife...

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: No! ...AND CUTS SAMUEL’S THROAT WIDE OPEN. The family SCREAMS in distress.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Oh God! My son! My son!

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Solomon! Stop him! William moans in agonized distress.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: My boy! Oh Samuel!  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 48 Eye-Patch looks down at SAMUEL’S DEAD BODY and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: EYE-PATCH
dialogues.text: This was the only man here. (to his companions) Take the girl. Kill the rest! Meredith is snatched away. Others grab Katherine, try to tear her away from William.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Solomon! Do something! Help us! Almost in a trance Kane takes a step towards Eye-Patch. Kane is transforming before our eyes. The steel is returning. The RAGE... The POWER...

dialogues.speaker: EYE-PATCH
dialogues.text: (drawing his sword) Come no nearer Puritan. Eye-Patch watches him, his black eye burning intensely. Kane calls to Katherine and William.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Would you have me slaughter these men?! Can that be justice enough?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Kill them! Kill them all!

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: (he turns his head up to heaven, quietly) Is that what you want? Is that all I am to you; a killer? Eye-Patch stands ready for anything now from this strange predatory man as Kane focuses all his intensity on him.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: If I take your life I am bound for hell. (a beat) It is a price I will gladly pay. Eye-Patch charges Kane, swinging his sword... ...but as the blade sweeps down on Kane he dodges to one side, takes the brute’s arm and SNAPS IT IN HALF.  48 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 49 He yanks away the sword, reverses it DRIVES THE BLADE TO THE HILT INTO THE MAN’S BODY, slicing upwards and GUTTING HIM. No human blood spills from these possessed soldiers only SLUDGE OF BLACK BILE AND RED SAND. Kane doesn’t miss a moment to consider the evil at work here. KANE turns savagely on the others who are rushing towards him now. The MASKED OVERLORD sits impassively watching it all. The RAIDERS have no chance as they attack Kane... For every SWORD thrust at him he replies with a DEADLY BL of his own. PISTOLS are fired but bullets go astray. It seems as if Kane is ten men, so consumed with his murderous rage. His feral howls of combat fills the air Some of the Raiders are more cowardly. They mount their horses and ride for safety. One of them hauls MEREDITH onto his mount. EDWARD grabs h but the Raider takes a pistol from his belt and SHOOTS EDWARD IN THE HEAD. WILLIAM struggles with another two raiders but is cut dow and stabbed by them. KATHERINE rushes to his side. Kane delivers one killing blow after another. LIMBS ARE SLICED, HEADS SEVERED. Kane is desperately fighting his way towards Meredith before she’s taken away but he simply can’t get through i time.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Solomon! Solomon! Don’t let them take her! But he cannot reach her. The OVERLORD wheels his steed about and leads his surviving raiders away through the trees even as Kane races on foot in pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KANE dashes after them but no matter how swiftly he runs the horses vanish into the distance ahead and loses sight of them in the mist and drizzle.  49 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 50 In fury he turns and races back to the forest clearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In thunderous silence KANE stalks through the devastated camp. The BODIES OF THE RAIDERS are all around. He picks through their corpses and clothing, seeking information. tears the INSIGNIA from the uniform of a dying Raider. As the creature draws its last breath it seems to CHANGE BAC INTO NOTHING MORE THAN A ROUGH LOOKING MAN. All the besti elements melt away with the rain. Kane considers this for a moment and then moves on. He steps past the bodies of EDWARD and SAMUEL as walks towar WILLIAM and KATHERINE. KATHERINE is cradling the dying WILLIAM in her arms. He h been mortally stabbed, his breath coming in short, bloody bursts. He looks to Kane.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Get her back. William speaks urgently, fighting for every breath.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Swear this oath to me now Kane. William grabs Kane and draws him near.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: By your own word you are a butcher and a murderer; you know how to kill like no man born. Do it. For me, for my family. Kill them all.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: My soul...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: This is how you will redeem your soul; Find my child and end this evil. The dying man holds Kane’s eyes with the last fire of his own.  50 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 1

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Swear your oath. Swear to God Almighty and He will protect your soul. Do it! Kane looks to Katherine; she want to hear it too. He take William’s hand in his own.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: I swear; I will find her and I will destroy this evil. William makes no show of having heard this... HE IS DEAD. Katherine cradles Williams body as Kane gently takes the locket from around William’s neck. He checks that the PICTURE OF MEREDITH is still within and then turns away. As THUNDER RUMBLES through the forest Kane snatches up a few essentials - SWORDS, KNIVES, a BRACE OF PISTOLS AND POWDER along with some provisions. Then he pulls a long black Puritan cloak about him and dons a wide brim black hat. This is SOLOMON KANE, the Puritan avenger, armed to the teeth and ready for the hunt, in all his glory. He takes the reins of a dead raider’s horse, swings himse up and charges away and into the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KANE is GALLOPING along the forest path. Ducking under branches and jumping fallen trees. His hat flies off but he makes no effort to retrieve it The DRIVING RAIN makes the ground treacherous and visibility poor but still Kane pushes the horse as fast a it can go. Up ahead he sees the faintest glimpse of the dark riders fleeing. Impossibly he forces his steed even faster... and gains on them.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE RIDERS UP AHEAD
dialogues.text: The group of FIVE RIDERS are pushing their own horses har One of them has MEREDITH bundled and covered across his saddle.  51 52 Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 82 Their LEADER sees KANE in the distance and indicates for two riders to split away and deal with him.

dialogues.speaker: ON KANE
dialogues.text: The TWO RIDERS appear parallel to him now; one on either side. Trees whipping past between them. They draw their swords and start to close in. Kane waits for them to attack... Then, still at full gallop, Kane takes his hands off the reigns and pulls out BOTH PISTOLS from his belt. Arms outstretched, he levels a gun at each attacker and pulls the triggers simultaneously. BOTH RIDERS crash from their horses. Without a second glance Kane rides on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The remaining riders BURST from the forest edge into open scrubby ground. Just the three of them left now but still pushing their horses hard. MOMENTS LATER... KANE charges from the trees. Riding like the devil himself and making ground on his quarry.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE RAIDERS
dialogues.text: Knowing that Kane is going to catch them they split up bu unerringly he follows the one carrying Meredith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RAIDER, still clutching the GIRL bundled up across hi horse, gallops through the broken remains of a STONE CIRC on these open moors. He turns and sees KANE closing the g second by second. There is no escape now. Within the stone circle he wheels his horse to a halt and turns to face Kane. The horse is exhausted, foaming at the mouth, breath coming in great steaming clouds. Kane keeps coming until he’s at the perimeter of the stones. He circles beyond the stones.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 583

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Give me the girl! Give me the girl!! The Raider drops the bundled up girl to the ground. She lies there stunned and exhausted. Kane dismounts and runs to her.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Meredith... (to the Raider) If she is harmed... He turns her over....IT IS NOT MEREDITH... ...just a YOUNG DARK-HAIRED GIRL. Weak and fearful. She recoils from Kane. Kane GRABS THE RAIDER and drags him down from his horse.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Where is she?! The Raider tries to fight but he can do nothing against Kane who beats him viciously.

dialogues.speaker: RAIDER
dialogues.text: There! You have her!

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: It is not her. Where is she? The girl you took from our camp? Meredith!?

dialogues.speaker: RAIDER
dialogues.text: I don’t know! I don’t know. Perhaps others have her. There are raiding parties all over. Kane draws his knife and presses it into the Raider’s fle beneath his eyeball.

dialogues.speaker: KANE
dialogues.text: Tell me what you know or I will pluck your eyes from your skull; where will they take her!? who is your master? Kane presses the knife into his flesh. Black blood trickl down his face. He screams in agony but then the SCREAM BECOMES A LAUGH.. ...the Raider suddenly begins TO SHAKE AND TWIST. His already scared and feral face contorts into a snarl, his eyes become black as old blood.  Solomon Kane by Michael J. Bassett 84 He stares at Kane and laughs. A hideous cackle that echoe around the broken stones. The Raider’s voice changes as i he’s suddenly possessed by an altogether more malicious spirit. It is a feral growl, filled with malice and thoug it comes from the mouth of the raider it seems to resonat all around them.

dialogues.speaker: RAIDER
dialogues.text: Solomon Kane... You may carve the flesh of this worthless body but it will not tell you what you want to know. I will not let it.
